name: Attachment-Based Family Therapy (ABFT)
summary: A manualized, evidence-based family therapy designed to repair ruptured parent–child relationships, reduce adolescent depression, and prevent suicidal ideation.
description: Attachment-Based Family Therapy (ABFT) is a short-term, empirically supported family therapy model rooted in attachment theory. It focuses on repairing ruptures in parent–child relationships that contribute to adolescent depression and suicidal ideation. By fostering secure attachment, emotional openness, and trust, ABFT helps adolescents develop resilience and reduces psychological distress. Treatment is structured, emotion-focused, and designed for adolescents and their families.

contraindications: Severe parental psychopathology that prevents engagement
clinical_metadata.evidence_level: Strong; multiple randomized controlled trials support efficacy.
clinical_metadata.research_support: Extensively studied with adolescents experiencing depression and suicidality.

sections.text: ABFT is based on attachment theory and posits that ruptures in parent–child attachment relationships contribute to adolescent depression and suicidality. The therapy strengthens emotional bonds through structured, emotionally focused sessions. By repairing attachment ruptures and fostering parental responsiveness, adolescents gain a secure base that reduces distress and promotes resilience.

sections.preparation: Assessment of family dynamics, attachment ruptures, and adolescent clinical presentation.
procedure: Initial alliance building with adolescent and parents.
Relational reframing of the adolescent’s symptoms as signals of relational distress.
Parent sessions to increase sensitivity, attunement, and reduce blame.
Adolescent sessions to prepare for expressing vulnerability.
Family sessions focused on repairing attachment ruptures and fostering secure communication.

sections.pre_session: Therapist prepares by reviewing family dynamics and identifying relational ruptures.
sections.treatment_phase: Structured sequence of individual and family sessions focusing on attachment repair and emotional communication.
sections.post_session: Therapist and family summarize progress and reinforce attachment-focused communication.
sections.home_practice: Encouragement of ongoing emotional openness and conflict resolution outside of sessions.

common: Emotional discomfort when discussing painful experiences
rare: Increased conflict if emotions are not well managed in therapy

special_considerations: Family willingness to engage is essential for success

ideal_candidates: Adolescents with depression or suicidal ideation
screening_required: Assessment for safety and readiness to engage in family therapy

practitioner: Licensed family therapists, psychologists, or social workers trained in ABFT

studies: Diamond, G.S. et al. (2002). Attachment-based family therapy for depressed adolescents: A treatment development study.
Diamond, G.S. et al. (2010). Attachment-based family therapy for adolescents with suicidal ideation: A randomized controlled trial.
Israel, P. et al. (2017). Attachment-based family therapy: A review of empirical support.
sections.limitations: Most research is focused on adolescents; adaptations for adults and other populations need further validation.

sections.total_treatment_cost: Varies; typically $2,000–$5,000 depending on session length and frequency
sections.insurance_coverage: Commonly covered under family therapy benefits
sections.cost_effectiveness: Cost-effective compared to hospitalization for suicidal adolescents

sections.adolescents: Primary target group; therapy designed for adolescents and their parents
sections.comorbidities: Adaptable for adolescents with comorbid anxiety or trauma

items: ABFT is a structured, manualized treatment with a strong evidence base.
Most effective with motivated families willing to engage emotionally.
Therapists require specialized training and supervision.
